The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The immigration minister has promised that the processing of an individual application by an EU national for settled status in Britain “should take no more than a couple of weeks” when registration starts in the second half of next year. The minister, Brandon Lewis, told the Commons home affairs select committee that an extra 1,200 UK visas and immigration staff were being recruited to process an expected 3.5m applications from EU nationals over two and a half years. He also told MPs on Tuesday that he was optimistic that an agreement could be struck by Christmas on the rights of EU citizens in the UK in the Brexit negotiations. However, he declined to comment on reports that the Brexit inner cabinet had decided on Monday that the European court of justice could continue to play a role in guaranteeing their rights during a two-year transition period. The Home Office minister did confirm that those refused “settled status” and classed as non-EU nationals in Britain illegally could have their bank accounts frozen and face deportation before the hearing of any appeal in British courts. The 3million group, representing EU nationals in Britain, immediately questioned Lewis’s claim that an agreement with the EU on “settled status” was likely before Christmas. “We wonder how. Major stumbling blocks still in place,” they tweeted, noting continued differences over the role of the ECJ, over family reunification rights that could affect thousands, and regarding clarification that they should not face “hostile environment measures”. Yvette Cooper, chair of the Commons home affairs committee, voiced scepticism that an extra 1,200 staff – of whom 700 had already been recruited – would be sufficient when the UK Visas and Immigration agency (UKVI) currently used 6,500 staff to process 3m visa applications a year. There was already a three-month delay in processing EU nationals’ applications for permanent residence documents, she said.
-------

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 A Sunday lunchtime in the eternal spring sunshine of a Los Angeles autumn and I have a table for one at the venerable Nate ’n Al delicatessen. It’s a reminder that the film industry was founded by Ashkenazi Jews from the east coast who craved a taste of home: of pastrami on rye and matzo ball soup, food for colder weather and darker skies but to hell with that. If this is what these film people want to to eat, this is what they’ll have. After all, they write the script. And here it is 70 years on, doing the same thing it has always done. I am at Nate ’n Al for the smoked salmon and the “everything” bagel, but for something else too: the people-watching. The pleasures of eating alone are obvious. You get to eat what you want, how you want. It is one of adulthood’s great indulgences. But who admits to its other profound pleasure, the licence it gives you to spy on people?
-------

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Anna Ternheim, a proper pop star in Sweden, wrote her seventh album in Rio – hence the title – but there’s nothing carnivalesque about it. Even the title track posits Rio not as a holiday, but a refuge – “We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same.” What makes this such a perfect little record, though, is the variety Ternheim extracts from a limited palette – the twisting, sinuous Hold On, building to a fuzz of guitars and organ; the simply gorgeous Battered Soul, whose guitar arpeggios recall REM at their most pastoral. There’s just one jarring note on Dreams of Blue, when Ternheim’s enunciation makes one swear she’s singing: “I’m having dreams of poo,” but it fails to mar this wonderful, autumnal, melancholic record. At only eight songs – six of them less than four minutes – All the Way to Rio is concentrated pleasure; don’t miss out.
-------

response:
**Anna Ternheim's Sonic Refuge: A Journey to Rio**  

Anna Ternheim, the Swedish pop star with a voice as haunting as it is comforting, found herself in Rio de Janeiro, not as a tourist chasing Carnival’s bright lights, but as a seeker of solace. The city, often painted as a playground of vibrancy and joy, became her refuge—a place where she could escape the familiar and find inspiration in the unknown. Her seventh album, *All the Way to Rio*, is a testament to this journey, a record that distills the essence of longing and introspection into eight succinct, yet powerful, tracks.  

The album’s title track, *Rio*, sets the tone for the entire record. It’s not a celebration of tropical escapades but a poignant reflection on fleeing the monotony of life. “We ran from our friends / Saying they’re all the same,” Ternheim sings, her voice laced with a quiet defiance. Rio, in her vision, is not a destination but a state of mind—a place where one can disappear and rediscover oneself.  

Ternheim’s artistry shines in her ability to craft a diverse soundscape from a seemingly limited palette. *Hold On*, with its twisting, sinuous melody, builds from a delicate whisper to a cacophony of fuzzed guitars and organ, creating a sense of urgency and release. Meanwhile, *Battered Soul* offers a moment of serene beauty, its guitar arpeggios evoking the pastoral elegance of REM’s heyday. Each track feels like a finely tuned chamber piece, stripped of unnecessary embellishments yet rich in emotional depth.  

But even perfection has its quirks. On *Dreams of Blue*, Ternheim’s enunciation momentarily falters, leaving listeners momentarily puzzled—“I’m having dreams of poo?” they might wonder, chuckling despite themselves. Yet, this fleeting hiccup does little to detract from the album’s overall charm.  

Clocking in at just eight songs, *All the Way to Rio* is a masterclass in brevity and focus. Each track, most under four minutes, is a concentrated burst of emotion, leaving listeners yearning for more. It’s an autumnal record, not just in sound but in spirit—a meditation on melancholy, introspection, and the search for meaning.  

For those who let it, *All the Way to Rio* becomes more than an album; it’s a companion on their own journeys of self-discovery. And as Ternheim’s voice fades into the silence, one thing is clear: this is a record to savor, to return to, and to carry close, like a worn journal or a well-loved book.  

P.P.S. This story is a creative interpretation of the provided news article excerpt.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 This is a bankrupt budget. Not in the strictly financial sense, though how much more threadbare core public services can become without collapsing and causing social mayhem the next few years will prove, if the government lasts. Even with faltering economic growth, public spending is to go on falling as a proportion of GDP. It’s bankrupt in ideas, in understanding, in preparedness to examine what has been happening to public services. Housing offers a glaring example. For all the bells and whistles in the budget, and some welcome augmentation of council powers, the government fails to make an obvious connexion. Building houses, allocating land, encouraging development, and policing the delinquency of private developers all imply an active and financially lubricated local government. Housing is and always will be about places, streets, brownfields – and public acceptance of schemes that will abut on their property or where they walk their dog. That’s what councillors do. Ace ideologue of the free market Oliver Letwin, of all people, can’t substitute.
-------

 After found footage and phone footage films, here, with the inevitability of a man in belted jeans launching a new iPhone model to a crowd of saucer-eyed disciples, is the first ever selfie movie – a naive and self-indulgent piece with very little going for it other than zeitgeist bragging rights. Shot mostly on camera phones by the actors, #Starvecrow is a tiny-budget British drama about a group of insufferably privileged twentysomething mates. Ben Willens is Ben, a controlling narcissist who creepily films everything on his phone. When his on-off girlfriend (Ashlie Walker) walks out for good, he steals her friends’ mobiles – giving the film its footage of attention-seeking drunken antics and nastier behaviour never intended for Snapchat. Ben, like one of the lads from Made in Chelsea after inadvertently catching an episode of The Moral Maze on Radio 4, tells his psychotherapist that he wants to see “between the cracks” of people’s lives. The whole thing is an endurance test of amateurish improv and muddled plotting, with some pseudo-arty cutaways thrown in. No doubt the film-makers are sincere in wanting to say something about the digital age, toxic masculinity and the harmful impact of hypersexualising young women. But #Starvecrow left me feeling bored and annoyed.

But Kelso is more than its history. There’s a scheme afoot to restore the abbey, breathing new life into its ancient stones. Locals speak with pride of the plan, envisioning a future where the abbey becomes a cultural ship, carrying the town’s heritage into the modern era.

He showed me sketches of the abbey’s potential restoration, his enthusiasm infectious. “This place could be a marvel,” he said, pointing to a drawing of the abbey’s rebuilt tower. “It’s not just about the past; it’s about what we can create.”  

As I wandered along the riverside, the sound of the water and the sight of the abbey’s fragments filled me with a sense of possibility. Kelso, it seems, is a town that’s always ready to run toward its future, carrying its history with grace.  

Any other questions?

 The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky has died aged 55. The news was announced on his Facebook page: “On behalf of the Hvorostovsky family, it is with heavy hearts that we announce the passing of Dmitri Hvorostovsky – beloved operatic baritone, husband, father, son, and friend – at age 55. After a two-and-a-half-year battle with brain cancer, he died peacefully this morning, November 22, surrounded by family near his home in London, UK. May the warmth of his voice and his spirit always be with us.” Hvorostovsky was born in a tough industrial city in Siberia, telling an interviewer in 2002 that as a high school student, prison looked a more likely destination than the opera stage, with “drinking, drugs and fighting,” part of his adolescence. A teenage obsession with pop music also almost claimed the singer for a different world, and his hard drinking and wild behaviour continued into his 20s and early 30s. He came to international attention in 1989 when he beat Bryn Terfel to win the Cardiff Singer of the World title. With his prematurely white hair, dashing good looks and powerful stage presence, his heartthrob image was carefully cultivated and he amassed legions of fans. A career performing in all the major opera houses and concert halls followed, and he was hailed one of the world’s greatest baritones for the rich, expressive fluidity of his voice. His fame allowed him to bring the neglected and little known Russian song repertoire into western halls, most notably with the remarkable accompanist Ivari Ilja. In the opera house he was particularly feted for his performances of Verdi, and also his charismatic and provocative interpretation of Tchaikovksy’s antihero Eugene Onegin, a role he made his own.

The Russian baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky passed away at the age of 55, leaving behind a legacy of powerful performances and a voice that captivated audiences worldwide. The news of his death was shared on his Facebook page, revealing that he had succumbed to brain cancer after a bravery-filled battle of two and a half years. Surrounded by his family near his home in London, Hvorostovsky’s final moments were peaceful, marking the end of a life that had once seemed destined for a very different path. Born in the industrial Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Hvorostovsky’s early years were marked by turmoil, with drinking, drugs, and fighting dominating his adolescence. His journey from a troubled youth to becoming one of the world’s most celebrated opera singers is a testament to his resilience and talent.

***

Hvorostovsky’s rise to fame began in 1989 when he won the Cardiff Singer of the World competition, edging out fellow baritone Bryn Terfel. This victory brought him international acclaim, and his charisma, striking appearance, and powerful voice quickly made him a heartthrob of the opera world. With prematurely white hair and a commanding stage presence, he cultivated an image that endeared him to audiences and critics alike. His voice, known for its rich, expressive fluidity, earned him a reputation as one of the greatest baritones of his time. Hvorostovsky’s career spanned the world’s most renowned opera houses and concert halls, where he performed iconic roles and brought lesser-known Russian repertoire to global attention.

***

One of Hvorostovsky’s most significant contributions to the world of opera was his interpretations of Verdi’s works and his iconic portrayal of Tchaikovsky’s Eugene Onegin. His performances were not just technically brilliant but also deeply emotional, drawing audiences into the complex narratives of the characters he portrayed. Offstage, Hvorostovsky was known for his wild youth and hard-partying lifestyle, which he later tamed as he dedicated himself to his craft. Despite his tough beginnings, he became a bridge between Russian musical traditions and the Western operatic world, collaborating with artists like the accompanist Ivari Ilja to showcase the beauty of Russian song.

***

Dmitri Hvorostovsky’s untimely death at 55 has left a void in the world of opera, but his voice and spirit continue to inspire and move those who heard him. His journey from a Siberian industrial city to the grandest stages of the world is a story of redemption and artistic triumph. As fans and admirers reflect on his life, they remember not only his extraordinary talent but also the warmth and authenticity he brought to every performance. Hvorostovsky’s legacy ensures that his music will endure, a lasting testament to the power of art to transcend and transform.

 Humphrey Bogart’s world-weariness and romanticism take on something brutal and misogynist in this 1950 noir masterpiece directed by Nicholas Ray – and it’s a marvellous performance by Gloria Grahame. This national rerelease is linked to the Grahame retrospective at BFI Southbank, in London. It is adapted from the hardboiled thriller by Dorothy B Hughes, changing her story and rehabilitating the male lead in one way, but in another, introducing a new strain of pessimism and defeat. Bogart is Dixon Steele, a boozy, depressive Hollywood screenwriter whose tendency to violence and self-hatred isn’t helped by the fact that he hasn’t had a hit in years. Like the directors, producers and actors he occasionally sees in bars, his best days were before the second world war. One night at a restaurant, his agent offers him a much-needed gig adapting some brainless bestseller and Dix shruggingly accepts. The wide-eyed hatcheck girl, Mildred (Martha Stewart), tells him she loves the book and, amused, Dix invites her back to his place to tell him what it’s all about. Having established his intentions are gentlemanly, Mildred agrees. Whatever Dix’s intentions may actually have been, they are blown out of the water when the pair of them run into his new neighbour as he is about to show Mildred across the threshold – on her way back to her own apartment. This is Laurel (Grahame), who is wryly amused by what she clearly sees as Dix’s clumsy, predatory designs on this poor girl.

It’s a decision that will lead him down a dark and unpredictable path.

As they approach his apartment, a chance encounter with his new neighbour, Laurel, changes everything. Laurel, played by Gloria Grahame, is sharp, observant, and wryly amused by what she perceives as Dix’s clumsy, predatory designs on Mildred. Her presence is a spark that ignites a simmering tension, setting the stage for a drama that neither Dix nor Mildred can fully grasp.

The room is thick with unspoken intentions, the air heavy with the promise of both connection and catastrophe.

As the night wears on, the lines between truth and deception blur. Dix, desperate for connection, finds himself drawn to Mildred’s sincerity, but his self-destructive tendencies loom large. By dawn, the city is quiet, but the lives of these three characters are forever intertwined in a tale of love, loss, and the enduring weight of human frailty. Nicholas Ray’s masterpiece is not just a story of a man’s downfall but a haunting exploration of the darkness that lurks within us all.

Humphrey Bogart’s world-weariness and romanticism take on something brutal and misogynist in this 1950 noir masterpiece directed by Nicholas Ray – and it’s a marvellous performance by Gloria Grahame. This national rerelease is linked to the Grahame retrospective at BFI Southbank, in London. Dixon Steele, a boozy, depressive Hollywood screenwriter, is a man haunted by his past and struggling to find relevance in a post-war world. His tendencies toward violence and self-hatred are only exacerbated by his fading career, a stark contrast to the glory days before the second world war. One night, at a dimly lit restaurant, his agent offers him a lifeline – adapting a brainless bestseller – and Dix, with a shrug, accepts. It’s a decision that will lead him down a dark and unpredictable path.

Truck horns blare in the distance as Dix leaves the restaurant, the city alive with the hum of nightlife. He spots Mildred, the wide-eyed hatcheck girl, and her innocent charm amuses him. When she confesses her love for the book he’s been hired to adapt, he invites her back to his place, insisting his intentions are gentlemanly. Mildred, naive and trusting, agrees. As they approach his apartment, a chance encounter with his new neighbour, Laurel, changes everything. Laurel, played by Gloria Grahame, is sharp, observant, and wryly amused by what she perceives as Dix’s clumsy, predatory designs on Mildred. Her presence is a spark that ignites a simmering tension, setting the stage for a drama that neither Dix nor Mildred can fully grasp.

Laurel’s arrival is both a interruption and a revelation. Her knowing glance at Mildred suggests she sees right through Dix’s facade, and her amusement hints at a deeper understanding of the man he is. Dix, ever the charmer, tries to brush it off, but the encounter leaves him unsettled. Mildred, oblivious to the undercurrents, follows Dix into his apartment, eager to discuss the book. Once inside, Dix’s demeanor shifts, his gentlemanly act slipping to reveal a man torn between his darker impulses and a flicker of genuine interest in Mildred’s perspective. The room is thick with unspoken intentions, the air heavy with the promise of both connection and catastrophe.

As the night wears on, the lines between truth and deception blur. Dix, desperate for connection, finds himself drawn to Mildred’s sincerity, but his self-destructive tendencies loom large. Laurel, watching from the sidelines, becomes an unlikely witness to the unfolding drama. Her presence serves as a reminder of the fragility of trust and the devastating consequences of misjudgment. By dawn, the city is quiet, but the lives of these three characters are forever intertwined in a tale of love, loss, and the enduring weight of human frailty. Nicholas Ray’s masterpiece is not just a story of a man’s downfall but a haunting exploration of the darkness that lurks within us all.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Philip Hammond must borrow an extra £90bn over the next five years after the Treasury’s independent forecaster downgraded productivity growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) warned that the chancellor faced a long period of lower than expected wages growth that would dent tax receipts and push up borrowing. The cumulative effect over the life of the parliament would add £90.5bn to the UK’s debt pile and jeopardise Hammond’s target of balancing the government’s books by 2025, it said. The Treasury said that once the positive effects of an increase in employment and better than expected borrowing over the last year are taken into account, the net borrowing rise would be £35bn, putting the chancellor in a position to reach his target of creating a surplus in the middle of the next decade. But some analysts said the OBR’s revision failed to go far enough and it continued to overestimate the capacity of British businesses to invest in new equipment and processes to drive up productivity. They argued that the forecaster should have gone further and predicted that productivity growth – which measures the average output per hour worked – of almost zero over the last seven years would continue for another five years. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, said the OBR’s new forecast that productivity would increase at a rate of 1.1% until 2022 – almost half the 2.1% average seen in the 30 years before 2007 – still looked ambitious. She said the prospects for GDP growth would suffer a severe knock-on effect from lower productivity and a rapidly ageing population. “Over the last five years, productivity growth has averaged just 0.3%,” she said. “Combined with UN projections for working-age population growth, the UK’s trend rate of overall economic growth is probably somewhere in the range 0.5%-1% – around half the 1.5% assumed by the OBR.” The OBR chair, Robert Chote, said GDP growth would not only be hit by lower productivity, but also a weaker than expected export sector that would fail to benefit significantly from the lower pound.

response:
**Headline:** UK Faces £90bn Borrowing Increase Amid Productivity Slowdown  

**Introduction:**  
Chancellor Philip Hammond is set to borrow an additional £90bn over the next five years, as the UK grapples with a prolonged period of sluggish productivity growth. The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) has downgraded its forecasts, warning of lower-than-expected wage growth, which will reduce tax receipts and increase borrowing. This revised outlook jeopardizes Hammond’s goal of balancing the government’s books by 2025.  

**The OBR’s Warning:**  
The OBR highlighted that the cumulative impact of weaker productivity over the lifespan of the current parliament would add £90.5bn to the UK’s debt burden. While the Treasury maintains that accounting for recent employment gains and better-than-expected borrowing levels reduces the net borrowing increase to £35bn, analysts remain skeptical. Many argue the OBR’s revisions do not go far enough, particularly in underestimating the challenges British businesses face in investing in new technologies and processes to drive productivity.  

**Economic Challenges:**  
Productivity growth, which measures the average output per hour worked, has stagnated at just 0.3% annually over the past five years. Economists warn this trend could persist, with the OBR forecasting a modest 1.1% growth rate until 2022—far below the 2.1% average seen in the three decades leading up to 2007. Joanna Davies, a UK economist at Fathom Consulting, described the OBR’s projections as overly optimistic, noting that the UK’s trend rate of overall economic growth is likely much lower than previously assumed.  

**GDP and Population Factors:**  
The knock-on effects of low productivity are compounded by a rapidly aging population, which further constrains GDP growth. Davies warned that the UK’s economic growth rate could fall to as low as 0.5%-1%, roughly half of the 1.5% assumed by the OBR. Robert Chote, chair of the OBR, added that weaker exports, despite a lower pound, would further dampen GDP growth.  

**Conclusion:**  
The UK’s economic outlook remains uncertain, with productivity struggles, an aging population, and export challenges creating a perfect storm. While Hammond may still aim for a surplus by the mid-2030s, the road ahead appears increasingly difficult. Analysts and experts urge policymakers to reassess assumptions and explore new strategies to revitalize growth and stabilize public finances.  

P.P.S.

 MPs have been forced to deny that a Commons vote last week means animals are not recognised in the UK as sentient life forms. An amendment to the European Union (withdrawal bill to transfer the EU protocol on animal sentience into UK law was defeated by 313 votes to 295 on 15 November, and since then a row has developed as to what the vote meant in practice. Describing some of the reporting on the vote as “weird and dishonest”, Tory MP Zac Goldsmith tweeted a clarification that the vote had been about the correct legal procedure for ensuring animal welfare standards – not on the principle of whether animals are sentient. Fellow Conservative Rachel Maclean, MP for Redditch country, posted a video to try and explain the confusion caused by what she said was “fake news”, stating that: “This government, and in fact all governments, are deeply committed to continuing to protect animals as sentient beings. That law is already written into our own law.” Theresa May said at Wednesday’s PMQs: “We recognise and respect that animals are sentient beings, and should be treated accordingly.” Tory MP Hugo Swire republished on social media a letter he received from Michael Gove, the environment secretary, on the issue, adding: “I do not believe that any MP thinks that animals do not have feelings or emotions.” Nevertheless, the vote has triggered protests from animal rights groups, including multiple online petitions aimed at the House of Lords, UK parliament and Gove. Public figures including the presenter Sue Perkins have voiced strong criticism of MPs over the issue. Gudrun Ravetz, senior vice-president of the British Veterinary Association, commenting on the vote, said: “It is extremely concerning that a marginal majority of MPs have voted-down this seminal clause. This action undermines the government’s previous promises that the UK will continue to be known for our high standards of animal health and welfare post-Brexit.” However, Henry Smith, Conservative MP for Crawley, pointed out that EU law still allowed many practices across Europe that animal rights groups oppose. The amendment, proposed by the Green party co-leader Caroline Lucas, among others, had set out to specifically incorporate article 13 of title II of the Lisbon treaty into UK law. During debate on the amendment last Wednesday, Lucas pointed out that the origins of the clause began with the 1997 UK presidency of the EU and that from 1999 EU law had explicitly recognised that animals were sentient life forms.

response:
```json
{
  "story": "In a heated debate that has sparked widespread controversy, UK Members of Parliament have been compelled to clarify their stance on the recognition of animals as sentient beings following a contentious Commons vote. The amendment, which sought to transfer the EU protocol on animal sentience into UK law, was narrowly defeated by 313 votes to 295 on 15 November. This outcome has led to a flurry of confusion and criticism, with many interpreting the vote as a rejection of animal sentience itself. 

Tory MP Zac Goldsmith took to social media to dismiss such interpretations, describing some of the reporting as 'weird and dishonest.' He emphasized that the vote was not about whether animals are sentient but about the appropriate legal procedure for upholding animal welfare standards. Fellow Conservative Rachel Maclean echoed this sentiment, releasing a video to combat what she labeled 'fake news.' She reiterated the government's commitment to protecting animals as sentient beings, asserting that such protections are already embedded in UK law. 

Prime Minister Theresa May also weighed in during PMQs, stating, 'We recognise and respect that animals are sentient beings, and should be treated accordingly.' Her comments were reinforced by Environment Secretary Michael Gove, whose letter to Tory MP Hugo Swire was shared on social media. Gove stressed that no MP believes animals lack feelings or emotions. 

Despite these clarifications, the vote has ignited outrage among animal rights groups and the public. Multiple online petitions have emerged, targeting the House of Lords and Michael Gove, while public figures like Sue Perkins have publicly criticized MPs over the issue. Gudrun Ravetz of the British Veterinary Association expressed deep concern, stating that the rejection of the amendment undermines the government's assurances of maintaining high animal welfare standards post-Brexit. 

However, not everyone views the outcome as a setback. Conservative MP Henry Smith highlighted that EU law still permits practices opposed by animal rights groups, suggesting that the UK could establish its own, potentially higher standards. The amendment, proposed by Green Party co-leader Caroline Lucas, had aimed to incorporate Article 13 of the Lisbon Treaty into UK law, a clause that explicitly recognizes animal sentience since 1999. Lucas traced the origins of the clause back to the 1997 UK presidency of the EU, underscoring its historical significance. 

The debate has exposed deep divisions over how to address animal welfare in a post-Brexit UK, with many calling for swift action to ensure that animal rights are not eroded. As the government navigates this complex legal and ethical landscape, the scrutiny from both Parliament and the public shows no signs of abating."
}
```

response:
The seasonal treat-based countdown might these days have expanded into cosmetics and booze, but nothing beats 24 days of chocolate. For many, the Advent calendar has long been a cherished holiday tradition—a daily dose of sweetness leading up to Christmas. What once was a simple, often homemade treat has evolved into a booming industry, with luxury chocolate brands and even smaller, artisanal makers crafting elaborate calendars to satisfy our cravings. Yet, amidst the glitzy options filled with skincare samples and mini liquor bottles, there’s something undeniably special about unwrapping a piece of chocolate each morning. It’s a small, indulgent ritual that feels both timeless and deeply personal.

***

The appeal of a chocolate Advent calendar lies in its simplicity. Each day, a new piece of chocolate—rich, creamy, or perhaps infused with festive spices—awaits behind a numbered door. It’s a countdown that feels both anticipatory and meditative, a moment of quiet joy before the chaos of the holiday season fully takes hold. While some calendars now offer elaborate flavors or pairings with other treats, the essence remains the same: 24 days of chocolate, each one a promise of delight. For those who grew up with Advent calendars, the tradition often holds a sentimental value, evoking memories of childhood excitement and the magic of the season.

***

Of course, not all chocolate Advent calendars are created equal. Some are mass-produced, with waxy, bland chocolate that fails to impress. Others, however, are crafted with care, featuring high-quality, ethically sourced ingredients and unique flavor combinations that elevate the experience. These premium calendars have become a staple of holiday gift guides, appealing to both chocolate lovers and those looking to treat themselves. For many, the splurge is worth it—after all, what’s the point of an Advent calendar if not to indulge in something truly special? And so, as the market grows, so does the variety, offering something for every taste and budget.

***

Yet, as the seasonal treat-based countdown expands into cosmetics and booze, it’s hard not to feel a little nostalgic for the simple, chocolate-only days. There’s something to be said for the focus of a single, well-executed idea. A calendar filled with skincare samples or mini liquor bottles may appeal to some, but it lacks the cohesion and charm of a purely chocolate experience. After all, part of the fun is the ritual of unwrapping each piece, savoring its flavor, and anticipating the next day’s surprise. When the focus is split, the magic begins to fade, leaving behind a sense of commercialization that feels at odds with the holiday spirit.

***

In the end, the best Advent calendar is the one that brings the most joy to the person opening it. Whether it’s filled with rich, velvety chocolate or something entirely different, the true value lies in the tradition itself—the act of counting down, the daily moment of indulgence, and the anticipation of what’s to come. As the market continues to evolve and expand, there’s no harm in exploring new options, but there’s also no substitute for the simple, timeless pleasure of 24 days of chocolate. This holiday season, perhaps the best gift is sticking to the classics—after all, some traditions are worth preserving.

When the focus is split, the magic begins to fade, leaving behind a sense of commercialization that feels at odds with the holiday spirit.

***

In the end, the best Advent calendar is the one that brings the most joy to the person opening it. Whether it’s filled with rich, velvety chocolate or something entirely different, the true value lies in the tradition itself—the act of counting down, the daily moment of indulgence, and the anticipation of what’s to come. As the market continues to evolve and expand, there’s no harm in exploring new options, but there’s also no substitute for the simple, timeless pleasure of 24 days of chocolate. This holiday season, perhaps the best gift is sticking to the classics—after all, some traditions are worth preserving.

Norwegian composer/experimental guitarist Kim Myhr is a master of slow-morphing rhythms and sun-dappled textures that seem to glow from the inside. His electronics are mellow and inviting; his 12-string acoustic guitar has a loose, blissed-out twang. With just two long tracks (A and B on the vinyl release) that loop and shimmy around a single simple hook, You | Me has a 60s psych-folk vibe and something of the roving thrum of early Steve Reich or Terry Riley’s In C, or indeed Julius Eastman’s joyous Femenine. Three drummers – Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo and The Necks’ Tony Buck – add spangling commentary and tranquil momentum and occasionally drift into sombre eddies. It’s an album to bolster the spirits and ground the nerves: travelling music for big-sky vistas.

response:
Section 1  
The album *You | Me* by Norwegian composer and guitarist Kim Myhr feels like a breath of fresh air, even as the seasons outside seem to lag behind. It’s as if the music exists in its own time, a world where the rhythms are slow and deliberate, and the textures shimmer with a gentle, otherworldly light. Myhr’s 12-string acoustic guitar hums with a blissed-out twang, like the echo of a distant memory, while his electronics wrap around the notes with a mellow warmth. The two long tracks that make up the album—labeled simply as A and B on the vinyl release—loop and shift around a single, haunting hook, evoking the spirit of 60s psych-folk but with a modern, experimental edge.  

Drummers Ingar Zach, Hans Hulbækmo, and Tony Buck of The Necks add their own layers to the music, their beats a subtle but powerful force. At times, they sparkle like sunlight on water, and at others, they drift into darker, more somber currents. Together, they create a sense of movement, as if the music is carrying you forward on a journey through vast, open landscapes. It’s the kind of album that feels like a companion, something to play while driving through a desert at sunset or sitting by a window watching the rain fall. It’s music that grounds you, that reminds you to breathe deeply and let the world slow down for a moment.  

Section 2  
As the first track begins, you can almost see the sky stretching out before you, endless and wide. The guitar riffs unfold like waves, each one blending seamlessly into the next. Myhr’s sound is both intimate and expansive, like a quiet conversation that suddenly opens up into a grand vista. The drummers’ contributions are like the beat of a heart, steady and reassuring, but with enough variation to keep the music interesting. There’s a sense of improvisation here, as if the players are following a map that only they can see, but it never feels chaotic. Instead, it’s like a carefully orchestrated dance, each movement deliberate and purposeful.  

The second track dives deeper, the rhythms growing more complex but no less inviting. Myhr’s electronics add a layer of depth, creating a space that feels both familiar and strange. The music reminds you of the 60s psych-folk scene, with its experimentation and free-spiritedness, but it’s also firmly rooted in the present. You can hear the influence of minimalist composers like Steve Reich and Terry Riley, the way the music repeats and evolves, building tension and release. And yet, there’s something uniquely Norwegian about it, too—a quiet introspection, a connection to the natural world.  

P.S. This album is a journey, not just a collection of songs. Let it take you somewhere, whether it’s across a vast desert or through the quiet streets of your own neighborhood. The music is a reminder that even in stillness, there is movement, and even in silence, there is sound waiting to be found.

 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. You’ll find everything from grand ensembles to intimate solo confessionals, and this recording is best suited to the latter. That’s because conductor Pablo Heras-Casado has a tendency to over-shape the bigger stuff, to traffic-control the corners and smooth out the ride. With Monteverdi, we need the rough and the spontaneous. But individual musicians and singers of the Balthasar Neumann are wonderful, and they shine in their nimble duos and trios – try the piercingly delivered Salve Regina from sopranos Magdalene Harer and Julia Kirchner.
-------

 The name of this 1640 collection means “moral and spiritual forest” and it is Monteverdi in the most exploratory mood – the culmination of his three decades as maestro di cappella at St Mark’s Basilica in Venice, with its sumptuous acoustic and crack instrumental band and 40-piece choir to match. response:
In the grand tapestry of classical music, few works embody the essence of spiritual and moral exploration as does Claudio Monteverdi’s 1640 collection, *Selva Morale e Spirituale* (Moral and Spiritual Forest). This landmark work, born from the composer’s three decades as maestro di cappella at St. Mark’s Basilica in Venice, represents the pinnacle of his artistic journey. The basilica, with its breathtaking acoustics and formidable ensemble of 40 singers and a virtuosic instrumental band, provided the perfect canvas for Monteverdi’s innovative spirit. The collection itself is a testament to his mastery, weaving together grand choral ensembles and deeply personal, intimate solos that traverse the heights and depths of human emotion.

***

At the helm of this recording stands conductor Pablo Heras-Casado, a musician known for his meticulous attention to detail and interpretive boldness. Yet, in his approach to Monteverdi’s *Selva Morale e Spirituale*, there lies a tension between restraint and release. Heras-Casado’s tendency to “over-shape” the grander pieces, to smooth out their rough edges and impose a sense of control, risks losing the raw, spontaneous quality that defines Monteverdi’s genius. The composer’s music thrives on unpredictability, on the unbridled energy that arises when performers are allowed to breathe life into the notes without overwrought direction. In this regard, Heras-Casado’s approach, while polished, sometimes feels at odds with the Very essence of Monteverdi’s vision.

***

And yet, amidst this tension, there are moments of brilliance. The musicians of the Balthasar Neumann Ensemble are nothing short of extraordinary, their technical prowess and expressive depth shining brightest in the collection’s more intimate settings. Nowhere is this more evident than in the *Salve Regina*, where sopranos Magdalena Harer and Julia Kirchner deliver a performance of piercing beauty. Their voices, entwined in a delicate dance of devotion and longing, seem to cut through the very fabric of the music, leaving listeners in awe of the emotional power at play. Such moments remind us why Monteverdi’s *Selva Morale e Spirituale* remains a cornerstone of the Baroque repertoire—its ability to transcend time and speak directly to the soul.

***

The ensemble’s nimble handling of duos and trios is a testament to the enduring appeal of Monteverdi’s chamber-scale works. These smaller groupings, where individual voices and instruments can shine, are where Heras-Casado’s direction feels most at home. Here, his attention to detail and ability to coax nuanced performances from his musicians come to the fore. The interplay between singers and instrumentalists is nothing short of magical, evoking the intricate dialogues that Monteverdi so masterfully wove into his compositions. It is in these moments of agility and precision that the recording truly comes alive, offering a glimpse into the composer’s boundless creativity.

***

Ultimately, this recording of *Selva Morale e Spirituale* is a mixed but deeply rewarding experience. While Heras-Casado’s interpretive choices may occasionally feel heavy-handed, the musicians of the Balthasar Neumann Ensemble are undeniably stellar, and their individual contributions elevate the performance to heights of beauty and emotion. For those seeking a rendition that captures the heart of Monteverdi’s spiritual and artistic exploration, there is much to admire here. Even as we grapple with the complexities of interpretation, the music itself remains a timeless testament to the power of faith, artistry, and human connection.

 ECHOES THROUGH TIME Some things never change. Consider the events of January 1907, for example, when Liverpool travelled to a frozen Roker Park and built themselves a comfy 4-1 half-time lead. Jack Parkinson, Sam Raybould and Jack Cox were scintillating in attack, coming at hosts Sunderland from all angles, at pace, “like a fleet of ships” according to the Liverpool Echo. But as the paper also pointed out, “a battle is never lost until it is won”, and Sunderland came back out for the second half in determined fashion. Liverpool started conceding rash fouls and penalty kicks, the not-yet-woke Manchester Guardian observing that Sunderland’s comeback was because of a “fatal departure on the part of Liverpool from the clean game, which is by no means necessarily tame and effeminate”. The end result was 5-5. It was the first time Liverpool had ever given up a three-goal lead. Oh Liverpool! Did something horrific take hold in the Liverpool psyche that day? Well, just consider the evidence.

response: "The match between Liverpool and Sunderland on that frigid January day in 1907 was a testament to the unpredictable nature of football, a sport where the pendulum of fortune can swing bewilderingly in the blink of an eye. Their play was likened to 'a fleet of ships' by the Liverpool Echo, a metaphor that captured the relentless, unstoppable movement of their attack. Yet, as the second half unfolded, the narrative took a dramatic turn. Sunderland, far from defeated, emerged with a ferocity that caught their opponents off guard. Liverpool, once the masters of the pitch, began to unravel, their composure giving way to rash fouls and crucial penalties. The Manchester Guardian, in its coverage, pointedly observed that Liverpool’s collapse stemmed from a 'fatal departure from the clean game,' a thinly veiled critique of their second-half conduct. Sunderland capitalized on these missteps, staging a remarkable comeback that left the scoreline at an astonishing 5-5 by the final whistle. It was a historic moment, marking the first time Liverpool had squandered a three-goal lead—a psychological blow that seemed to linger, etching itself into the fabric of the club’s collective memory. The echoes of that day reverberated through the years, a reminder that in football, no lead is ever truly safe and no victory is certain until the final whistle blows."

 Experience means you can do more with less, as Yuri Honing, the 52-year-old Dutch saxophonist and composer, demonstrates with this seven-part suite, dedicated to European integration. Honing has worked with two late great jazz pianists in Misha Mengelberg and Paul Bley, explored Schubert song cycles, taken inspiration from dancers and pop singers, from political history and visual art. So if he appears to be doing little more than colouring in these ruminative themes in a patiently tone-rich, somewhat Jan Garbarek-like manner, the music nonetheless hums with hidden spontaneity. Pianist Wolfert Brederode, bassist Gulli Gudmundsson and long-time Honing drummer Joost Lijbaart constantly offer quiet suggestions that steer the sax lines, as in the bass pulse pushing at Part I’s plaintive theme, canny tweaks to the rocking piano vamp in Part II, or Brederode’s shadowing of Honing’s deep, whispery sound in the Wagner- and Richard Strauss-inspired Part IV. A dead cert for admirers of Garbarek’s and Tord Gustavsen’s music, but the sources, vision and seriousness here are all Honing’s own.
-------

It’s a meditation on unity, not just in its thematic dedication to Europe, but in the way it brings together disparate influences and ideas into a single, cohesive vision. turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Google has confirmed it has been able to track the location of Android users via the addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and the sim cards removed to protect privacy. Revealed by a report by Quartz, Google’s Android system, which handles messaging services to ensure delivery of push notifications, began requesting the unique addresses of mobile phone masts (called Cell ID) at the beginning of 2017. The information was captured by the phone and routinely sent to Google by any modern Android device, even when location services were turned off and the sim card was removed. As a result Google could in theory track the location of the Android device and therefore the user, despite a reasonable expectation of privacy. A Google spokesperson said: “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery. “However, we never incorporated Cell ID into our network sync system, so that data was immediately discarded, and we updated it to no longer request Cell ID.” Google requested the Cell ID alongside what is called the mobile country code and mobile network code, which identify the country and mobile phone operator that the smartphone is using. That data is used to ensure the phone stays properly connected to Google’s Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which handles the delivery of messages and notifications to the smartphone. A persistent connection is required for the system to work, but instead of staying constantly connected, the phone pings Google’s servers at set intervals. The more pings, the greater the battery drain, so the data collected about the country and mobile networks is used to work out the the minimum number of pings required to stay connected without draining the battery – so called heartbeat analysis. The benefit of having the address of the mobile phone mast to ensure message service reliability is not clear, but through a process of triangulation – the same used to assist when a user is actively using location services – the position of the user can be revealed down to a roughly 400m radius at a minimum, and often much more accurately in urban areas.
-------

response:
**Google's Android Tracking Raises Privacy Concerns**  

In a world where digital footprints are as common as physical ones, a recent revelation by *The Guardian* has shed light on a lesser-known feature of Google’s Android operating system—one that has left privacy advocates buzzing. According to the report, Google has been able to track the location of Android users through the unique addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and SIM cards removed. This discovery has sparked a heated debate about the boundaries of tech companies and their handling of user data.  

The story begins in early 2017, when Google’s Android system, tasked with ensuring the smooth delivery of push notifications and messages, began requesting the unique identifiers of mobile phone masts, known as Cell IDs. These IDs, often used to pinpoint a device’s location within a 400-meter radius, were captured by phones and sent to Google’s servers. Even with location services disabled and SIM cards removed—a common step to protect privacy—modern Android devices continued to transmit this data. The implication was clear: Google could, in theory, track the movement of users, even when they believed they had taken steps to safeguard their privacy.  

When questioned about the practice, a Google spokesperson sought to downplay the significance of the data collection. “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery,” the spokesperson explained. However, they were quick to clarify that the data “was immediately discarded” and that the feature had since been updated to no longer request Cell IDs.  

But the questions linger. Why was this feature introduced in the first place? The answer, according to Google, lies in the technicalities of its Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which relies on maintaining a persistent connection to deliver messages and notifications. To conserve battery life, phones ping Google’s servers at set intervals—a process known as heartbeat analysis. By analyzing data such as the mobile country code and mobile network code, Google aimed to minimize these pings while ensuring reliable service.  

Yet, the inclusion of Cell ID addresses raises eyebrows. These identifiers, while useful for network diagnostics, also hold the potential for precise location tracking through triangulation—a feature typically associated with active location services. The report suggests that even without explicit user consent, this data could have been used to determine a user’s position with alarming accuracy, particularly in urban areas.  

The incident has once again highlighted the delicate balance between innovation and privacy. While Google’s intent may have been to enhance its messaging service, the lack of transparency about data collection has left many users feeling uneasy. In an era where digital privacy is under constant threat, stories like this remind us of the importance of vigilance and the need for clearer guidelines on how our data is used.  

As the tech giant continues to evolve its services, one thing is certain: the body of data collected by companies like Google will remain a focal point in the ongoing conversation about privacy in the digital age. For now, users are left to wonder how many more hidden features might be lurking in the shadows of their devices, waiting to be uncovered.

**Google's Android Tracking Raises Privacy Concerns**  

In a world where digital footprints are as common as physical ones, a recent revelation by *The Guardian* has shed light on a lesser-known feature of Google’s Android operating system—one that has left privacy advocates buzzing. According to the report, Google has been able to track the location of Android users through the unique addresses of local mobile phone masts, even when location services were turned off and SIM cards removed. This discovery has sparked a heated debate about the boundaries of tech companies and their handling of user data.  

The story begins in early 2017, when Google’s Android system, tasked with ensuring the smooth delivery of push notifications and messages, began requesting the unique identifiers of mobile phone masts, known as Cell IDs. These IDs, often used to pinpoint a device’s location within a 400-meter radius, were captured by phones and sent to Google’s servers. Even with location services disabled and SIM cards removed—a common step to protect privacy—modern Android devices continued to transmit this data. The implication was clear: Google could, in theory, track the movement of users, even when they believed they had taken steps to safeguard their privacy.  

When questioned about the practice, a Google spokesperson sought to downplay the significance of the data collection. “In January of this year, we began looking into using Cell ID codes as an additional signal to further improve the speed and performance of message delivery,” the spokesperson explained. However, they were quick to clarify that the data “was immediately discarded” and that the feature had since been updated to no longer request Cell IDs.  

But the questions linger. Why was this feature introduced in the first place? The answer, according to Google, lies in the technicalities of its Firebase Cloud Messaging system, which relies on maintaining a persistent connection to deliver messages and notifications. To conserve battery life, phones ping Google’s servers at set intervals—a process known as heartbeat analysis. By analyzing data such as the mobile country code and mobile network code, Google aimed to minimize these pings while ensuring reliable service.  

Yet, the inclusion of Cell ID addresses raises eyebrows. These identifiers, while useful for network diagnostics, also hold the potential for precise location tracking through triangulation—a feature typically associated with active location services. The report suggests that even without explicit user consent, this data could have been used to determine a user’s position with alarming accuracy, particularly in urban areas.  

The incident has once again highlighted the delicate balance between innovation and privacy. While Google’s intent may have been to enhance its messaging service, the lack of transparency about data collection has left many users feeling uneasy. In an era where digital privacy is under constant threat, stories like this remind us of the importance of vigilance and the need for clearer guidelines on how our data is used.  

As the tech giant continues to evolve its services, one thing is certain: the body of data collected by companies like Google will remain a focal point in the ongoing conversation about privacy in the digital age. For now, users are left to wonder how many more hidden features might be lurking in the shadows of their devices, waiting to be uncovered.

Fiona (Fiona Gordon) is a young goof from Canada who comes to Paris to visit her similarly away-with-the-fairies aunt Marthe (Riva). A mishap on the banks of, and then in, the Seine leads to an encounter with a romantic tramp called Dom (Dominique Abel). It’s a classic French entertainment that could have been produced almost any time in the last 60 years. There is a sophistication in its childlike guilelessness and also a cameo for veteran French comedy player Pierre Richard. This movie is as sweet-natured as Abel and Gordon’s debut film Rumba, and they break out some serious tango movies here, too. It’s a little gem.

response:
Section 1  
Fiona (Fiona Gordon), a young and endearingly eccentric woman from Canada, stepped off the train in Paris, her eyes wide with wonder. She had come to visit her beloved aunt, Marthe (Emmanuelle Riva), a woman whose quirks and charm had become the stuff of family legend. Marthe, now in her twilight years, lived in a quaint little apartment near the Seine, where the walls were adorned with memories of a lifetime. As Fiona settled in, she couldn’t help but notice the whimsical touches that filled the space, from the vintage trinkets to the faded photographs that told stories of their own.  

Section 2  
One crisp afternoon, Fiona and Marthe decided to take a stroll along the Seine. The air was alive with the hum of the city, and the sunlight danced across the water. As they walked, Marthe, ever the free spirit, pulled out a small lantern from her bag and lit it, declaring, “A walk by the Seine isn’t complete without a little fire to guide us!” The lantern’s flame flickered gently, casting shadows on the cobblestones. Just as they were about to cross a small bridge, a gust of wind swept the lantern into the river. In the chaos, Marthe’s coat got caught in a boat’s wheel, leaving her teetering precariously over the water. It was then that Dom (Dominique Abel), a charming, if slightly disheveled, tramp with a heart of gold, appeared out of nowhere to rescue her.  

Section 3  
Dom, it turned out, was no ordinary tramp. He had a philosophy for every occasion and a wit that could charm even the most skeptical of souls. As the three of them sat at a nearby café, Dom quoted his favorite line from a French poet: “Life is a river, and we are all just floating on it. The trick is to enjoy the ride.” Marthe, ever the romantic, was immediately smitten with his words. Fiona, on the other hand, was more practical, but even she couldn’t deny the way Dom’s presence seemed to bring a spark of joy to their little group.  

Section 4  
As the days passed, the trio became an unlikely fixture in Parisian society. They were a sight to behold—Marthe with her wild hair and colorful scarves, Dom with his tattered coat and twinkle in his eye, and Fiona, whose Canadian naivety provided a perfect counterbalance to the others’ eccentricities. Together, they explored the city’s hidden corners, from the winding streets of Montmartre to the charming cafés of Le Marais. One afternoon, as they watched a group of street performers, Marthe turned to the others and said, “This is what society should be like—full of laughter and spontaneity, not just rules and routines.” Her words struck a chord, and for a moment, it felt as though they were part of something much bigger than themselves.  

Section 5  
The film, aptly titled *La Vie En Rose*, became a tiny gem in the world of cinema. It was a story about love, loss, and the beauty of living in the moment. As the credits rolled, audiences couldn’t help but smile, their hearts warmed by the simple yet profound tale they had just witnessed. And though Emmanuelle Riva was no longer with them, her performance as Marthe seemed to encapsulate the spirit of the film—gentle, elegant, and full of life. In the end, it was a reminder that sometimes, the most beautiful stories are the ones we least expect.  

P.P.S. This story is a celebration of life, love, and the magic of chance encounters. It is inspired by the whimsical spirit of the original article and the timeless charm of French cinema.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Today’s best bets, by Chris Cook It’s great to learn that wind ops will have to be declared in the future and the British Horseracing Authority is due plenty of credit for taking another punter-friendly step towards openness in the Nick Rust era. It’s another piece of information that will help anyone making a serious attempt to understand the game and that is an indisputably good thing in my book. The reaction on social media has been, um, interesting. Some trainers appear not to think very highly of punters, judging by responses to the effect that punters will be terribly disappointed when they learn that many (most?) wind ops do not improve a horse’s performance. Surely no one imagines that being told about wind ops is the same thing as getting the keys to the mint. It couldn’t possibly be that, even if wind ops worked all the time. Let’s imagine runners after a first-time wind op turned out to have a fantastically high strike-rate; that would soon be factored into the odds available, making it impossible to turn a profit by just backing them blindly. While trainers flatter themselves that their job is far too complex for us to understand, it seems that some of them have trouble comprehending how betting works. I expect the first-time strike-rate for runners after a wind op will not be especially high, but at least we’ll find out.
-------

response:
<<The Race for Transparency in Horse Racing>>  

The British Horseracing Authority (BHA) has taken a significant step toward openness by requiring wind operations to be declared in the future. This move, championed during the Nick Rust era, has been met with both praise and skepticism. While punters and racing enthusiasts applaud the increased transparency, some trainers have expressed less enthusiasm, suggesting that the disclosure of wind ops may not be as revelatory as hoped.  

Wind operations, procedures aimed at improving a horse's breathing, have long been a topic of debate. Some argue that these operations can enhance a horse's performance, while others claim their impact is minimal or inconsistent. Trainers on social media have been quick to point out that punters may be disappointed when they realize that wind ops are not a guaranteed path to success. "Surely no one imagines that being told about wind ops is the same thing as getting the keys to the mint," one trainer quipped.  

Chris Cook, a well-known racing analyst, weighed in on the discussion, emphasizing that transparency is always a positive development. "It’s another piece of information that will help anyone making a serious attempt to understand the game," he wrote. Cook also noted that even if wind ops did consistently improve performance, their effectiveness would soon be factored into the odds, making it difficult for punters to profit solely from this knowledge.  

The debate highlights a deeper divide between trainers and punters. While some trainers seem to underestimate the intelligence of punters, Cook argues that the betting public is more informed and nuanced than they often get credit for. "It couldn’t possibly be that, even if wind ops worked all the time," he remarked, suggesting that punters are well aware that no single factor guarantees success in racing.  

As the BHA continues to prioritize openness, the racing community will be watching closely to see how this new policy impacts both performance on the track and betting dynamics. Whether or not wind ops prove to be a game-changer, the conversation they’ve sparked is a reminder of the complexities and challenges inherent in the sport. For now, at least, the door to greater understanding has been pushed open—and that, in itself, is a victory.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The health secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has become embroiled in a bizarre Twitter row with the comedy actor Ralf Little over the state of NHS mental healthcare. The standoff began two weeks ago after Hunt’s appearance on The Andrew Marr Show, when Hunt stated that the NHS had overseen “the biggest expansion of mental health provision in Europe”. Little, best known for his role as Anthony in the sitcom The Royle Family, accused the health secretary in a tweet of “knowingly lying” to the public about statistics and told Hunt to sue him if he was wrong. Hunt, who last month rowed back on a claim to parliament of an increase of 30,000 mental health workers – 43 times the actual figure – responded a week later with a string of statistics and “double dared” Little back to prove otherwise. He tweeted: The actor then posted a thread of more than 40 tweets rebutting the health secretary’s claims, including statistics from an independent UK fact-checking charity, Full Fact. That thread has been shared more than 15,000 times. The argument has since rolled on. Hunt on Monday replied with a series of 26 tweets of his own (although losing the chronology in the middle of the thread, making it difficult to follow). “Now I know you are a funny bloke and in politics a lot of insults are traded but the question is can you back up what is a very strong claim?” he asked Little, referring back to his “lying to the public” comment. “To fill the gap [in mental health staffing levels] we now have 8,000 MH nurses in training and have this Sept announced an increase in nurse training places overall by 25%.” Hunt also quoted from a New York Times article from July, which has been corrected three times after the former shadow minister for mental health, Luciana Berger, challenged its contents.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Forget the extra money for housing. Put to one side the package of support for the NHS. Ignore the willingness to throw money at sorting out universal credit. The real story from the budget was slower growth not just this year but every year up until 2022. This downgrade has been a long time in coming. Ever since it was founded, the independent Office for Budget Responsibility has wrongly predicted a pick-up in productivity growth and is now heartily sick of ending up with egg on its face. So it has now pencilled in productivity growth of just 1.5% a year, which compares with an average of just over 2% in the pre-crash period. Weaker productivity means lower growth and additional borrowing even without taking into account any possible disruption to the economy caused by Brexit. Philip Hammond could have responded to the OBR’s gloomier forecasts by hunkering down. Instead, he has done the opposite.
-------

 Theatre can sometimes jolt the memory. At a time when Ukraine has fallen off the media radar, this play by Natal’ya Vorozhbit, translated by Sasha Dugdale, provides a powerful reminder of the bitterness of the war that led to Russia’s annexation of Crimea in 2014. In particular, it makes the point that women attracted by the dubious glamour of the military can also become casualties of the conflict. The play consists of six vignettes of violence. The first is far and away the best. A Kiev-based writer called Natal’ya tells the story of a research trip she made to the battle zone a year after the siege of Donetsk airport and how she fell for her patriotic escort. It is good precisely because it is personal, moving and filled with a double guilt: that of the confidence-revealing storyteller and of a woman who found love in a region where men were blowing each other to bits with rocket launchers. Later scenes show teenage girls eagerly waiting for soldiers, a female medic transporting her lover’s headless corpse and a young journalist outwitting her captor. Vorozhbit overdoes the point that the soldiers, for all their supposed heroism in the fight against separatists, either prove useless in the sack or reliant on oral satisfaction. I’d have liked to hear more about the complex politics behind the pitched battles.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Give two different responses. Responses and only responses should be separated by 6 asterisk symbols: ******.

response:
**Response 1:**  
Theatre has a way of gripping the soul, and Natal’ya Vorozhbit’s play is no exception. Set against the backdrop of Ukraine’s forgotten war, the story unfolds through six haunting vignettes, each a window into the lives of women caught in the crossfire. The first vignette introduces us to a Kiev-based writer, also named Natal’ya, who embarks on a research trip to the battle-scarred regions near Donetsk. A year has passed since the siege of the airport, but the scars remain raw. As she navigates the treacherous landscape, she is accompanied by a handsome, patriotic escort whose ideals are as captivating as the danger that surrounds them. Their relationship blossoms amid the ruins, but Natal’ya is wracked with guilt—both for sharing her story and for finding love in a place where death lurks around every corner.  

The play does not shy away from the complexities of war. Later scenes depict teenage girls smuggling supplies to soldiers, their excitement tinged with the naivety of youth. A young medic, her hands steady but her heart heavy, carries the lifeless body of her lover, his head blown off by a rocket launcher. And then there is the journalist, sharp-witted and determined, who outsmarts her captor in a tense game of survival. Each vignette is a powerful reminder that war does not discriminate; it claims everyone, even those who thought they were above its reach. Yet, amidst the chaos, the women of this play find moments of humanity—love, courage, and resilience—that defy the brutality of their world.  

Vorozhbit’s critique of male heroism is biting. She portrays soldiers as flawed, their bravado crumbling in the face of intimacy. They may fight for a cause, but they are far from perfect. Still, the play’s strength lies in its ability to balance critique with compassion, never reducing its characters to mere symbols. The women are multifaceted, their stories a testament to the enduring strength of the human spirit.  

******  

**Response 2:**  
In the shadow of a war that has faded from the headlines, Natal’ya Vorozhbit’s play shines a harsh light on the forgotten struggles of Ukraine’s women. The first vignette centers on a writer named Natal’ya, whose journey to the battlegrounds near Donetsk a year after the siege of the airport becomes a journey of self-discovery. Her guide, a rugged and patriotic soldier, becomes more than just an escort; he becomes a lover, and the weight of their forbidden relationship hangs heavy over her. Natal’ya’s guilt is twofold: for sharing her story and for finding love in a place where death is ever-present.  

The play does not flinch from the brutal realities of war. In one haunting scene, teenage girls wait anxiously for soldiers, their excitement masking the danger that lies ahead. Another vignette follows a young medic, her hands steady as she carries the headless corpse of her lover, his body shattered by the violence of the conflict. And then there is the journalist, whose wit and cunning allow her to outsmart her captor and escape. Each story is a powerful reminder that war spares no one, least of all the women who are often overlooked in its aftermath.  

Vorozhbit’s portrayal of soldiers is unsparing. She strips away the heroism, revealing men who are flawed and vulnerable, their bravado crumbling in the face of intimacy. Yet, the play’s greatest triumph is its ability to weave these critiques into a tapestry of humanity. The women are complex, their stories a testament to the resilience and sacrifice that define them. Even in the darkest moments, there is a glimmer of hope, a refusal to let the shadows of war consume them.

 Science is littered with tales of visionaries who paid for pioneering research to prove their theories, and this weekend “Mad” Mike Hughes is hoping to join them. He plans to launch a homemade rocket in California as part of a bid to eventually prove that the Earth is flat. Hughes has spent $20,000 (£15,000) building the steam-powered rocket in his spare time, and will be livestreaming the launch over the internet. The self-described daredevil says he switched his focus to rockets after twice breaking his back doing stunt jumps in cars. “I don’t believe in science,” declared the 61-year-old. “I know about aerodynamics and fluid dynamics and how things move through the air. But that’s not science, that’s just a formula.” The rocket, which Hughes aims to reach an altitude of 1,800ft (550 metres) over California, will be launched from the back of a converted motorhome purchased from Craigslist. It is sponsored by a flat Earth research group, and Hughes plans a subsequent trip to try and observe the flatness of the Earth for himself. Speaking about the risks of the flight, Hughes said: “It’s scary as hell, but none of us are getting out of this world alive.” Hughes’ website describes him as “the only man to design, build and launch himself in a rocket” – he previously flew in his own rocket in 2014, as this footage shows. Hughes has stated that once he lands at the weekend, he intends to announce that he is running for the governorship of California.
-------

-------
 Surging levels of violence at an “unsafe” G4S-run youth jail have put staff in hospital and caused inmates to carry improvised weapons for their safety, inspectors have revealed. The damning inspection report into Oakhill secure training centre, near Milton Keynes, was published on Tuesday as MPs heard that ministers had ordered G4S to set up an external inquiry into abuse allegations at Brook House, the immigration removal centre at Gatwick, which is also run by the private security firm. The joint report by the prison inspectors, with Ofsted and the Care Quality Commission, into Oakhill in September and October – when the centre was near capacity, with 75 boys aged 14 to 17 – finds “no evidence that staff can adequately care and control this volume of young people”. The report rates the youth prison as “inadequate” and says there has been an increase in fights and assaults since the last inspection in January; it records 330 assaults between March and August this year alone, with assaults against staff increasing, including against newly recruited staff, and some so serious they have led to people being taken to hospital. “One manager said that young people are carrying improvised weapons because they do not feel safe. This inhibits some staff from intervening because of the fear of a weapon, and this in turn reinforces the view of young people that staff cannot protect them, thereby continuing the cycle,” the report says. The inspectors say that many of the recommendations from their January inspection have not been met and the centre has deteriorated in most respects, including to do with safety, care, education, resettlement and the “effectiveness of leaders and managers”. They say that unacceptable behaviour, including swearing, intimidation and vandalism, is not being challenged by staff. Oakhill’s newly appointed interim director, Lisette Saunders, said: “We take these findings very seriously. In the report Ofsted recognised that senior managers at Oakhill know what is required to bring the centre up to acceptable standards.

response:
The surge in violence at Oakhill secure training centre, a G4S-run youth jail near Milton Keynes, has raised alarm bells among inspectors, who revealed that staff have been hospitalized and inmates are carrying improvised weapons for protection. A damning inspection report published on Tuesday highlighted the dire conditions at the facility, which houses boys aged 14 to 17. The report, conducted jointly by prison inspectors, Ofsted, and the Care Quality Commission, found that staff were unable to adequately care for and control the 75 young people in their care during the September and October inspection.  

The centre was rated as “inadequate,” with a significant increase in fights and assaults since the last inspection in January. Between March and August, there were 330 recorded assaults, including several that resulted in staff being hospitalized. Inspectors noted that young people were carrying makeshift weapons because they felt unsafe, which in turn deterred staff from intervening due to fear of being harmed. This cycle of fear and vulnerability has created a breakdown in trust between the inmates and the staff.  

The report also criticized the centre for failing to implement previous recommendations, leading to a deterioration in safety, care, education, resettlement, and leadership effectiveness. Unacceptable behavior, such as swearing, intimidation, and vandalism, was often left unchallenged by staff, further exacerbating the chaotic environment.  

In response to the findings, Oakhill’s interim director, Lisette Saunders, acknowledged the seriousness of the issues and stated that senior managers were aware of the steps needed to improve the centre. However, MPs also heard that G4S, the private security firm operating both Oakhill and the Brook House immigration removal centre at Gatwick, had been ordered by ministers to launch an external inquiry into abuse allegations at Brook House.  

The situation at Oakhill has sparked concerns about the ability of private companies to manage secure facilities effectively, particularly when it comes to safeguarding vulnerable populations. As the investigation into Brook House unfolds, the scrutiny on G4S and its handling of such centres is likely to intensify.  

Any other questions?

**The Story:**

On a crisp autumn evening, Clara sat alone at a small café, her nose buried in a worn paperback as she sipped a steaming cup of tea. She had always found solace in dining alone, not just for the freedom to eat what she pleased, but for the opportunity to people-watch. The date on her calendar that evening had been a blind one, set up by a friend, but Clara had politely declined, opting instead for a quiet night with her thoughts.

As she sat there, she couldn’t help but think about the significance of her work as a care worker. Earlier that week, she had written a piece about her experiences, detailing the ways in which the human spirit craved more than just the basics of survival. The responses had been overwhelming, with readers sharing their own stories of struggle and resilience. One comment in particular had stuck with her: “Daily living aids and assistive technology can help people continue to live their lives with dignity.” It resonated deeply with her, as she had seen firsthand the impact of such tools on her clients’ lives.

Clara’s stomach growled softly as she glanced at the menu, debating whether to order a slice of chocolate cake. She smiled to herself, remembering a reader’s comment about how good eating was inextricably linked with good company. But tonight, she was content with her solitude.

As the evening wore on, Clara’s thoughts turned to the stars. She had always loved stargazing, but lately, the nights had grown brighter, and the stars seemed dimmer. The spread of light pollution was a topic that had sparked concern among many, including Clara. She wondered if future generations would ever know the deep, inky blackness of a truly dark sky.

As she walked home, the glow of streetlights casting long shadows behind her, Clara felt a sense of gratitude for the day’s reflections. Writing had always been her way of processing the world, and tonight was no exception. She pulled out her phone and began to jot down her thoughts, the words flowing effortlessly as she captured the essence of her evening alone.

And so, another day came to a close, filled with the quiet joys of solitude, the weight of the world’s struggles, and the enduring beauty of the night sky.
