But who admits to its other profound pleasure, the licence it gives you to spy on people?” You responded with some of your own experiences. ‘I’ve met some interesting people that way’ ‘Good eating for me is inextricably linked with good company’ ‘I take a good book and do some people-watching’

What being a care worker taught me: the human spirit needs more than the basics Community care worker, Sarah Beauclerk wrote about her moving experiences as a care worker which prompted readers to talk about what they learned looking after others. ‘This job taught me some things about our society that I strongly criticise and hate’ ‘Daily living aids and assistive technology can help people continue to live their lives with dignity’

Why the nights are getting brighter - but not in a good way Many of you who like to look up at the stars were concerned to hear satellite observations show light pollution is spreading and affecting the level of darkness across the world.

---

**The Story:**

On a crisp autumn evening, Clara sat alone at a small café, her nose buried in a worn paperback as she sipped a steaming cup of tea. She had always found solace in dining alone, not just for the freedom to eat what she pleased, but for the opportunity to people-watch. The date on her calendar that evening had been a blind one, set up by a friend, but Clara had politely declined, opting instead for a quiet night with her thoughts.

As she sat there, she couldn’t help but think about the significance of her work as a care worker. Earlier that week, she had written a piece about her experiences, detailing the ways in which the human spirit craved more than just the basics of survival. The responses had been overwhelming, with readers sharing their own stories of struggle and resilience. One comment in particular had stuck with her: “Daily living aids and assistive technology can help people continue to live their lives with dignity.” It resonated deeply with her, as she had seen firsthand the impact of such tools on her clients’ lives.

Clara’s stomach growled softly as she glanced at the menu, debating whether to order a slice of chocolate cake. She smiled to herself, remembering a reader’s comment about how good eating was inextricably linked with good company. But tonight, she was content with her solitude.

As the evening wore on, Clara’s thoughts turned to the stars. She had always loved stargazing, but lately, the nights had grown brighter, and the stars seemed dimmer. The spread of light pollution was a topic that had sparked concern among many, including Clara. She wondered if future generations would ever know the deep, inky blackness of a truly dark sky.

As she walked home, the glow of streetlights casting long shadows behind her, Clara felt a sense of gratitude for the day’s reflections. Writing had always been her way of processing the world, and tonight was no exception. She pulled out her phone and began to jot down her thoughts, the words flowing effortlessly as she captured the essence of her evening alone.

And so, another day came to a close, filled with the quiet joys of solitude, the weight of the world’s struggles, and the enduring beauty of the night sky.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The world is changing as new technologies rip through old economies. The prospect of life outside the European Union will alter how we trade, move goods and people around and make our way in the world. For a long time these questions about the future have been neglected by national governments – left to the market, to globalisation, to Brussels. Now we need active change. To provide it, the government is launching its industrial strategy white paper, which will be published next Monday and heavily trailed during this week’s budget. In a welcome move, Theresa May has already outlined how the government plans to increase public and private R&D investment by up to £80bn over the next 10 years. The prime minister also announced £1.7bn to improve transport links within city regions. This comes as the UK is in serious need of new thinking to address fundamental long-term economic challenges: poor productivity, unbalanced regional growth and a weak track record in translating knowledge creation into inclusive wealth creation. The impact of the financial collapse in 2008 and the recent decision to leave the EU have only exacerbated these deep-seated national problems. A long-term industrial strategy for the UK that includes proper investment in R&D and connectivity is overdue.
-------

 This compilation of a score of up-and-coming Brit acts has plenty to commend it, but its adopted “alt-folk” tagline proves fanciful. Most tracks are by gentle singer-songwriters of conventional hue, while the wilder reaches of wyrd folk - encounters with shape-shifters on stormy moors – are almost entirely absent. There are some forceful characters on display nonetheless. Brooke Sharkey offers airy, Anglo-French chamber folk. Ferris and Sylvester combine dreamy pop with spiky sentiments on Save Yourself (alt Simon and Garfunkel perhaps) and seven-piece Mishaped Pearls bring a cinematic sweep to Six Dukes. A rewarding sampler of a vibrant live scene, and not-for-profit with it.

The dim glow of the village hall flickered over the packed crowd, all gathered to celebrate the rising stars of Britain’s folk scene. The air hummed with anticipation as the compilation, trumpeted as “alt-folk,” promised something groundbreaking. But as the first notes of Brooke Sharkey’s ethereal voice drifted through the room, it became clear that this was no wild jaunt into the supernatural realms of wyrd folk. Her Anglo-French chamber folk, airy and delicate, set the tone for a night of nuanced, grounded artistry.

Ferris and Sylvester took the stage next, their dreamy pop intertwined with sharp, spiky sentiments that drew comparisons to a darker Simon and Garfunkel. The crowd swayed, entranced, as the duo’s harmonies danced like shadows on the walls. Then came Mishaped Pearls, a seven-piece ensemble that swept the room into a cinematic crescendo. Their haunting melodies and lush arrangements painted vivid stories of love and loss, leaving the audience breathless.

The night was a testament to the vibrant live scene thriving just beneath the mainstream radar. And with the compilation being not-for-profit, it wasn’t just a celebration of music—it was a labor of love.

P.P.S.

In one of the most notorious incidents involving the actor and director, Gibson unleashed an antisemitic rant in 2006 against a police officer in Malibu, California, who had pulled him over for drunk driving. He accused Jews of being responsible for “all the wars in the world”. He was convicted of driving under the influence. His latest comments come after dozens of women alleged they had been sexually harassed or assaulted by Weinstein.

In 2010, it was reported that tapes had been submitted to the courts of Gibson allegedly using racist language and threatening to kill Grigorieva. He is also alleged to have said she deserved a beating. In one of the most notorious incidents involving the actor and director, Gibson unleashed an antisemitic rant in 2006 against a police officer in Malibu, California, who had pulled him over for drunk driving. He accused Jews of being responsible for “all the wars in the world”. He was convicted of driving under the influence. His latest comments come after dozens of women alleged they had been sexually harassed or assaulted by Weinstein.

As the debate over Gibson’s remarks continues, one thing is clear: the Hollywood sexual harassment scandal has opened up a broader conversation about accountability and change. For now, the industry is left to navigate the complexities of redemption, forgiveness, and the long road to true equality.

response:
Theresa May is facing increasing pressure to secure a clear Brexit transition agreement by March, as businesses grow weary of the uncertainty surrounding the UK's exit from the EU. The Institute of Directors (IoD) has warned that without a firm political agreement, companies will be forced to activate contingency plans, including relocating operations out of the UK. Stephen Martin, the IoD's director general, is set to deliver this ultimatum at the organization's annual dinner, emphasizing the urgent need for progress. "All we want for Christmas is progress on Brexit," he will say, highlighting the frustration felt by business leaders.

Smell of uncertainty lingers in the air as companies brace for the worst-case scenario. Martin will point out that over half of IoD members are already engaged in contingency planning, though only about one in 10 have implemented these plans so far. However, this number is expected to "snowball" if clarity on Brexit is not provided soon. The IoD has urged the government to act swiftly, warning that the window of opportunity to secure a transition agreement is narrow—between now and the end of the first quarter of 2024. Without such an agreement, businesses will be left with no choice but to implement their contingency plans, potentially leading to significant disruptions.

The prospect of transitioning to World Trade Organization (WTO) rules is particularly concerning for businesses. Martin will describe this as a "huge drop down from where we are now," noting the massive complexity involved in adjusting customs procedures and the potential loss of access to the single market. Additionally, the UK would risk losing the trade and investment agreements it currently benefits from through the EU. While businesses are reluctantly preparing for this scenario, Martin will stress that it is not the desired outcome. "WTO is not the simple option," he will say, underscoring the challenges it poses.

As the clock ticks down to March, the stakes for Brexit negotiations could not be higher. Martin will appeal to the government to prioritize securing a transition agreement, emphasizing the need for stability and predictability in cross-border trade. With businesses already on edge, the IoD is urging swift action to avoid a chaotic no-deal scenario. The message is clear: progress on Brexit is not just a Christmas wish—it is a necessity. Any other questions?

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 This is Philip Hammond’s first budget statement since the general election in June and the third since he became chancellor last year. In March he was cheered by his backbenchers after the UK avoided the recession predicted by many analysts following the Brexit vote last year. Employment was climbing and measures of consumer and business confidence, which plummeted after the referendum, had bounced back. But he was soon in deep trouble with his Tory colleagues for planning a one percentage point increase in national insurance on the self-employed and, in a humiliating U-turn, he was forced to ditch the whole idea. The election in June left Hammond further weakened. He needs to push through measures that improve the economy’s productivity to have any chance of meeting his pledge to eliminate the UK’s deficit by the mid-2020s, but is also facing pressing problems in public services, welfare provision and a housing market that has effectively locked a generation of young people out of home ownership. Economy What we know: The UK economy expanded by 1.7% in 2016 but registered just 0.5% growth in the first half of this year. The pace has improved since the summer largely due to improving growth rates in Europe and the US, but the outlook remains weak. What to look out for: The Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) is expected to downgrade the 2% GDP growth it was expecting for 2017 back in March to about 1.5%. Growth expectations for the next four years are also likely to be lowered.
-------
Please generate a story based on the sentences provided.  Include keywords ['bell', 'education', 'meat', 'muscle', 'painting'] in the response. Your response should contain at least 11 sentences.

response:
Philip Hammond stepped into the House of Commons to deliver his first budget statement since the June general election, a moment many viewed as a bell tolling for his political career. The chancellor, already weakened by the election results, faced a daunting task: balancing the UK’s fragile economy while addressing mounting pressures in public services, welfare, and housing. The economy, once hailed as resilient after the Brexit vote, now showed signs of strain. Growth had slowed to 0.5% in the first half of 2017, though a summer rebound, fueled by stronger European and US markets, offered a glimmer of hope. Still, the outlook remained weak, with the Office for Budget Responsibility expected to downgrade its GDP growth forecast for the year from 2% to 1.5%.  

Hammond knew the meat of his budget needed to address productivity, a critical factor in meeting his pledge to eliminate the deficit by the mid-2020s. But with Tory backbenchers still smarting from his aborted national insurance hike on the self-employed, he had little room for maneuver. Critics argued that years of austerity had left public services, particularly education, in dire need of investment. Schools were struggling to retain teachers, and universities faced uncertainty over funding, casting a shadow over the nation’s future workforce.  

As Hammond outlined his plans, he emphasized the importance of education and training in building the economy’s muscle. He announced new initiatives to boost apprenticeships and vocational training, aiming to equip young people with skills for the modern workforce. However, questions lingered about whether these measures would be enough to offset decades of underinvestment. Meanwhile, the housing crisis continued to paint a bleak picture, with young people locked out of homeownership and forced to rely on an increasingly unaffordable rental market.  

The budget was a balancing act, with Hammond trying to please both fiscal hawks and those clamoring for greater spending. As he spoke, the reality of a weakened economy loomed large, with growth forecasts for the next four years likely to be revised downward. The chancellor’s challenge was clear: restore confidence, stimulate growth, and ensure the UK could weather the storms of Brexit and beyond. The bell had tolled for Hammond’s moment to act, and the nation watched to see if he could rise to the occasion.

Still, the outlook remained weak, with the Office for Budget Responsibility expected to downgrade its GDP growth forecast for the year from 2% to 1.5%.  

Hammond knew the meat of his budget needed to address productivity, a critical factor in meeting his pledge to eliminate the deficit by the mid-2020s. But with Tory backbenchers still smarting from his aborted national insurance hike on the self-employed, he had little room for maneuver. Critics argued that years of austerity had left public services, particularly education, in dire need of investment. Schools were struggling to retain teachers, and universities faced uncertainty over funding, casting a shadow over the nation’s future workforce.  

As Hammond outlined his plans, he emphasized the importance of education and training in building the economy’s muscle. He announced new initiatives to boost apprenticeships and vocational training, aiming to equip young people with skills for the modern workforce. However, questions lingered about whether these measures would be enough to offset decades of underinvestment. Meanwhile, the housing crisis continued to paint a bleak picture, with young people locked out of homeownership and forced to rely on an increasingly unaffordable rental market.  

The budget was a balancing act, with Hammond trying to please both fiscal hawks and those clamoring for greater spending. As he spoke, the reality of a weakened economy loomed large, with growth forecasts for the next four years likely to be revised downward. The chancellor’s challenge was clear: restore confidence, stimulate growth, and ensure the UK could weather the storms of Brexit and beyond. The bell had tolled for Hammond’s moment to act, and the nation watched to see if he could rise to the occasion.

 An appeal against a ban on Silvio Berlusconi holding public office is to be heard by the European court of human rights, in a move that could potentially see Italy’s scandal-tainted former prime minister leading the country again. The hearing on Wednesday, six years after he was forced from office, follows his success at forging a winning coalition out of his centre-right Forza Italia and two far-right parties – the Northern League and Brothers of Italy – in regional elections in Sicily earlier this month. The outcome of the ballot on the southern Italian island was largely seen as a rehearsal for how things might play out in national elections, which must be held before May next year. It also marked the beginning of an authentic political comeback for the 81-year-old, despite being plagued by a tax fraud conviction, sex scandals and allegations of corruption. Considering the length of time it takes for the court to deliver a verdict, it is unlikely to come before the general elections. The current five-year term for the Italian government officially expires on 15 March, although the vote could be held as late as May. “I hope that the Strasbourg court will accept my appeal,” Berlusconi wrote on Twitter on Wednesday. “But my role in the next electoral campaign is clear regardless: I will be in the field looking to take the centre-right into government.” The billionaire, who was forced to resign from his third term as prime minister in 2011 over claims he paid for sex with an underage sex worker, has hired top lawyers from London’s Doughty Street Chambers to fight his case. He was ejected from parliament and banned from running for office for six years in 2013 due to his tax fraud conviction. “We’ll have just 30 minutes to set out our argument, the same goes for the government,” Andrea Saccucci, one of the lawyers who will represent Berlusconi in the Strasbourg court, told the Guardian.

 ‘My motto is: try everything, life is short,” says John Dwyer, the leader of San Francisco garage rockers Thee Oh Sees. “We are growing at every turn. Every day you get a little older, a little closer to the grave – you should taste it all.” A master of contemporary garage rock, he came into prominence as part of the fruitful San Francisco scene of the early 2000s. Since then Thee Oh Sees have rattled out 21 LPs of bewilderingly consistent quality, under various iterations of their name, and Dwyer has written, recorded and released another 20 albums with other collaborators, encompassing everything from industrial electronics to improvised jazz and death metal. In a recent interview with Marc Maron, Dwyer talked of his love of Scott Walker and, in particular, a scene in the Walker documentary 30th Century Man when a percussionist is recorded punching a side of beef; Dwyer has similarly tried to master new sounds, be it a flute on Thee Oh Sees’ Dog Poison or electronic bagpipes on his most recent Damaged Bug LP. His career is full of examples of how to explore genres on a shoestring, too – there are projects that are just drums and vocals (the Drums) or a hefty death metal record squeezed out of three people (Dig That Body Up, It’s Alive). We asked him where to begin in his vast back catalogue. Coachwhips – Bangers vs Fuckers (Narnack, 2003) Coachwhips rewrote the punk aesthetic for the 21st century. Raw, stripped back to the bones of guitar, drums and keys, their shows were chaotic and rambunctious. Bangers vs Fuckers epitomises that, squeezing 11 tracks into 18 minutes, and was notable for Dwyer’s use of a telephone transducer rather than a microphone.

The Polish government maintains that it always behaves lawfully and that logging in Białowieża is necessary to staunch a spruce bark beetle outbreak. “In the western media, everything is based on disinformation,” a Polish government spokesman told the Guardian. “We are doing everything right by law.

But when the Huddersfield contemporary music festival began, in 1978, the situation was much worse, with no annual showcase here for what living composers were producing. That such an event took root in an unprepossessing West Yorkshire industrial town in the late 70s was remarkable in itself, especially when most of the activity in new music then was centred on London. What began on a modest scale under the aegis of Huddersfield Polytechnic (now the University of Huddersfield) – where the festival’s tireless founding director, Richard Steinitz, was a lecturer in music – grew quickly into one of the most important dates in the British musical calendar. The HCMF really hit its stride in the early 80s, hosting a series of important premieres alongside residencies from many of the senior figures of postwar music, from Olivier Messiaen and Terry Riley to Hans Werner Henze and Elliott Carter. Gradually expanding its ambition and range, Steinitz’s programming was never narrowly doctrinal; from the early days, he tried to reflect the spectrum of what was going on across Europe and the US. Steinitz stood down as director after the 2000 festival. The current director, Graham McKenzie, has been there for more than a decade, not only steering the programming towards new generations of composers from across Europe, but also broadening the stylistic scope, including events that touch on jazz, electronica and rock. With these changes, so the atmosphere of the festival has altered. This is partly because the generation of postwar composers whose appearances made the early festivals so memorable has all but gone, but also because, in those days, festival audiences had a sense of a shared purpose.
-------

But he’d had a good few hard races the year before and he seemed to come out of it very well.” Sizing John is only seven, rising eight, and he looked a picture yesterday.

Section 1  
The sun rose over Jessica Harrington’s bustling yard, where the air was thick with anticipation. Sizing John, the reigning Gold Cup champion, stood at the center of attention, his powerful frame and gleaming coat a testament to his status as one of racing’s elite. Harrington, a seasoned trainer with a no-nonsense approach, had already begun mapping out the season for her star chaser. She knew the challenges ahead, but her focus was clear: to guide Sizing John back to the Gold Cup, a feat few recent winners had achieved.  

Section 2  
Harrington’s remarks about the fragile nature of staying chasers resonated deeply within the racing community. She pointed to the examples of Coneygree and Don Cossack, both of whom failed to return to the Gold Cup after their victories. This harsh reality underscored the immense physical and mental toll of competing at the highest level. For Sizing John, who had already endured three grueling races the previous season, the stakes were even higher. Yet, Harrington remained optimistic, recalling how the horse had bounced back after similarly demanding campaigns in the past.  

Section 3  
As the team at the yard went about their morning routine, Harrington couldn’t help but express her concerns. “My only worry,” she admitted, “is maybe the three hard races last year might leave a mark on him.” But she quickly balanced this with confidence, noting that Sizing John had proven his resilience before. At just seven years old, rising eight, the horse still had plenty of life left in him. His condition yesterday was exemplary, his spirit undimmed by the rigors of his career.  

Section 4  
For now, all eyes are on the Gold Cup. Harrington’s “Plan A” is clear: get Sizing John to the starting line in peak condition. What happens after that is secondary, a bonus for a horse that has already achieved so much. As the yard buzzed with activity, there was an unspoken understanding that this season could define Sizing John’s legacy. Time will tell if he can defy the odds and return to the pinnacle of the sport, but one thing is certain: Jessica Harrington and her team will leave no stone unturned in their pursuit of glory.

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 Concordia International, the Canadian drug company, has overcharged the NHS by more than £100m in the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug, according to Britain’s competition watchdog. The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had provisionally found that Concordia had “abused its dominant position to overcharge the NHS” by hiking the price of liothyronine, used to treat patients with an underactive thyroid, by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. The regulator said the NHS had spent more than £34m on the drug last year, up from about £600,000 in 2006. The amount it paid per pack rose from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017. The price of a single pill went up from 16p to £9.22, even though production costs remained broadly stable during that period, the CMA said. Concordia could be fined up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover. Liothyronine tablets are used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition caused by a deficiency of the thyroid hormone that affects at least two in 100 people and can lead to depression, tiredness and weight gain. For many patients there is no alternative and, until this year, Concordia was the only supplier. This summer, the UK firm Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva were granted licences to supply the drug. The medicine, a synthetic version of the hormone T3, is taken by patients who do not respond well to the cheaper alternative, levothyroxine.
-------

response:
"Concordia International, a Canadian drug company, has been accused by Britain’s Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) of overcharging the NHS by more than £100m over the past decade for a life-changing thyroid drug. The drug, liothyronine, is used to treat hypothyroidism, a condition that affects at least two in 100 people and can lead to symptoms such as depression, tiredness, and weight gain. The CMA provisionally found that Concordia had abused its dominant market position by hiking the price of the drug by nearly 6,000% between 2007 and 2017. The NHS spent more than £34m on liothyronine last year, compared to just £600,000 in 2006, with the cost per pack rising from £4.46 in 2007 to £258.19 by July 2017. The price of a single pill skyrocketed from 16p to £9.22 during the same period, despite production costs remaining stable.

Strategy played a crucial role in Concordia’s ability to inflate prices. As the sole supplier of liothyronine in the UK for many years, the company held a monopoly over the market. This dominance allowed Concordia to set prices without fear of competition, effectively exploiting the NHS and patients who had no alternative treatment. The lack of competition meant that the company could incrementally increase prices, knowing that the NHS had no choice but to pay. The CMA’s investigation revealed that Concordia’s pricing strategy was not only exploitative but also harmful to patients who relied on the drug for their health and well-being. The watchdog noted that such practices undermine trust in the pharmaceutical industry and place an unnecessary burden on public healthcare systems.

The consequences of Concordia’s actions could be severe. The CMA has stated that the company could face a fine of up to 10% of its worldwide annual turnover if found guilty of abusing its market position. This would serve as a significant deterrent to other pharmaceutical companies contemplating similar strategies. Additionally, the entry of new competitors, such as UK-based Morningside Healthcare and Israel’s Teva, has already begun to challenge Concordia’s dominance. Both companies were granted licenses to supply liothyronine earlier this year, marking a turning point for patients who have long been at the mercy of Concordia’s pricing.

While the introduction of new suppliers offers hope for more competitive pricing, the damage caused by Concordia’s decade-long price hikes cannot be easily undone. Patients who rely on liothyronine have faced significant financial strain, with many struggling to afford the life-changing medication. The NHS, already under financial pressure, has also borne the brunt of these inflated costs. The case highlights the need for stricter regulations and greater transparency in the pharmaceutical industry to prevent such abuses of power in the future. As the CMA continues its investigation, the hope is that justice will be served, and patients will no longer be exploited for their essential medications."

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Turnbull government has deployed new modelling on the national energy guarantee in an effort to step up pressure on state governments to sign up to its policy at a meeting of energy ministers on Friday. A summary of the modelling, circulated by the government in advance of the talks with the states, suggests household power bills between 2020 and 2030 would be “in the order of” $120 a year lower, in today’s dollars, than under a business-as-usual scenario, if the policy applied across the national electricity market. The material supplied by the government says wholesale electricity prices would be 23% lower than business-as-usual between 2020 and 2030, and it suggests the share of renewables in the market by 2030 “could range from 32% to 36%”. The full modelling, undertaken for the Energy Security Board by Frontier Economics, has not yet been distributed to state energy ministers and the documents circulated in Canberra are a summary of the findings, not the work itself. The Turnbull government announced in October it would dump the clean energy target recommended by the chief scientist, Alan Finkel, and proceed with the national energy guarantee – a policy that imposes new reliability and emissions reduction guarantees on energy retailers and large energy users from 2020. The policy requires cooperation from the states but some of the Labor governments, particularly South Australia, have been hostile. Part of the reason for that is the states were involved in the exhaustive consultations with Finkel about the clean energy target but were not kept in the loop about the national energy guarantee. Some state governments are also concerned the Turnbull policy will hard-bake coal into the system at the expense of renewables at a time when the energy market needs to transition to low-emissions power sources. A spokesman for the South Australian premier, Jay Weatherill, is continuing to insist that the state will not commit to sign on to the national energy guarantee in the absence of data showing its specific impact on the state. The Labor states have also commissioned their own work through the Council of Australian Governments energy council examining whether or not they could implement a clean energy target by themselves.
-------

* This is point 1. 
* This is point 2

response:
"The incident began on a sweltering evening in Darwin, as the sun dipped below the horizon, casting long shadows over the Stuart Highway. Dale Scott Walkinshaw, a 23-year-old man with a history of struggles, was behind the wheel of his Toyota Hilux, speeding down the highway after a night of drinking at a local bar. His passenger, a young woman he had met earlier that evening, sat beside him, her laughter echoing through the open windows. But the night took a deadly turn when Walkinshaw lost control of the vehicle, crashing into a palm tree on the corner of Bargot Road, just a short distance from Darwin airport.

As the car crumpled against the tree, Walkinshaw stumbled out, dazed but unharmed. He rushed to the passenger side, where the young woman lay slumped, her body limp and unresponsive. Panicked, he pulled her into his arms, trying to rouse her as blood trickled from a deep gash on her back. The scene was chaotic, the air thick with the smell of alcohol and the sound of crickets filling the silence.

Unbeknownst to Walkinshaw, two police officers were nearby, responding to a noise complaint in the area. They arrived at the crash site just as Walkinshaw was tending to his injured passenger. The officers quickly assessed the situation, calling for an ambulance as they took Walkinshaw into custody. A breathalyzer test revealed his blood alcohol level was 0.149, well over the legal limit.

What followed was a series of events that would later come under intense scrutiny. Walkinshaw, clearly intoxicated and visibly distressed, was placed in the back of a police van. Despite his agitated state, the officers failed to monitor him closely. The van, like many others in the Northern Territory police fleet, was not equipped with CCTV cameras, a recommendation that had been ignored for years despite a previous death in custody.

In the hours that followed, Walkinshaw’s condition deteriorated. He became increasingly agitated, his movements becoming more erratic as the minutes ticked by. The officers, unaware of the danger unfolding in the back of the van, continued their patrol, leaving Walkinshaw alone and unmonitored. It wasn’t until they arrived at the police station that they discovered the tragic outcome: Walkinshaw had taken his own life, his body found semi-conscious and unresponsive in the caged vehicle.

The incident sent shockwaves through the community, raising urgent questions about the adequacy of police procedures and the failure to implement critical safety measures. The coroner’s investigation revealed a stunning negligence: in the three years between the first recommended installation of CCTV cameras and Walkinshaw’s death, there had been at least 16 attempted suicides in police vehicles. In six of those cases, the individuals were not detected until they were semi-conscious or unconscious, a grim statistic that underscored the inevitability of such a tragedy.

NT coroner Greg Cavanagh delivered a scathing report, criticizing the police for their inaction. He noted that it wasn’t a matter of if a person would die in the back of a police van but when. The death of Dale Scott Walkinshaw was a preventable tragedy, one that might have been avoided if the police had acted on the recommendations of their own internal report years earlier.

In the aftermath of the incident, the Northern Territory police faced intense scrutiny, with calls for accountability and systemic change. The death of Walkinshaw became a rallying cry for advocates pushing for improved oversight and better treatment of vulnerable individuals in custody. As the community grappled with the loss of a young life, one thing became clear: the failure to act had cost a man his future, and it was a mistake that could never be undone."

turns:
The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The Czech tennis player Jana Novotná, who has died of cancer aged 49, had a career of consistent success that would have more than satisfied most players, but fell some way short of what she would have achieved had she possessed a much steadier nerve. In 1998, the year before she retired, Novotná became only the fifth female player to pass the $10m mark in career prize money and in the same year was within reach of being ranked No 1 in the world. As an athlete she was among the best of her era, possessed of consummate skill in the dying and difficult art of serve-and-volley and an ability to deliver a backhand smash that was the envy of her peers. And yet in her 14 years at the top of the women’s game she won only 24 tour singles titles. Even more disappointingly, she reached the last eight in 22 of the 50 grand slam singles events in which she competed but managed to convert that consistency into just one title. The American player and commentator Pam Shriver, who was a good friend, explained this by saying that Novotná was “as kind as she was athletic”. Others, mostly tennis writers such as myself, put it more brutally: she was a choker. Novotná herself said she hated the idea of choking, preferring instead to say that she “got a little tight”. Her most famous episode of getting a little tight is now a case study for sports psychologists. It came in the 1993 Wimbledon final when she led Steffi Graf 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and at 40-30 in the sixth game of the deciding set had a service point for a 5-1 lead over the German.
-------

response:
SECTION 1  
Jana Novotná, the Czech tennis player whose career was marked by both brilliance and heartbreak, left an indelible mark on the sport. Despite her untimely death at 49, her legacy endures as a testament to her skill, determination, and resilience. Novotná’s journey began in Brno, Czechoslovakia, where she first picked up a racket as a child. Her natural talent and dedication quickly set her apart, and by the time she turned professional in the late 1980s, she was already considered one of the most promising young players in the world. Her unique style, blending precision, finesse, and a rare mastery of the serve-and-volley technique, made her a formidable opponent on the court.  

SECTION 2  
Throughout her 14-year career, Novotná achieved numerous milestones that solidified her place among the tennis elite. In 1998, she became only the fifth female player to earn more than $10 million in prize money, a staggering feat at the time. That same year, she was on the brink of reaching the world No. 1 ranking, a distinction that would have capped off her remarkable journey. Yet, despite her consistent success, Novotná struggled with converting her opportunities into Grand Slam titles. She reached the quarterfinals in 22 of the 50 Grand Slam singles events she competed in but managed to secure only one major singles title. This disparity between her promise and performance became a defining narrative of her career.  

SECTION 3  
The 1993 Wimbledon final remains one of the most poignant moments in Novotná’s career—and a case study in the fragility of mental fortitude in sports. Facing Steffi Graf, Novotná was on the verge of victory, leading 6-7, 6-1, 4-1, and holding a service point for a 5-1 lead. What followed was a collapse that would haunt her for years to come. She lost the game, the set, and eventually the match, succumbing to the pressure of the moment. This loss, more than any other, encapsulated the tension between her extraordinary skill and her struggles with nerves. As sports psychologists later analyzed, Novotná’s inability to close out matches when it mattered most was not a lack of talent but a recurring mental hurdle.  

SECTION 4  
Despite her struggles, Novotná’s impact on tennis could not be overstated. Her mastery of the serve-and-volley game, a style that was rapidly disappearing in an era dominated by baseline play, inspired a generation of players to embrace the artistry of net play. Off the court, her kindness and sportsmanship earned her the respect and admiration of her peers. Pam Shriver, a close friend and fellow player, often spoke of Novotná’s generosity and warmth, qualities that set her apart in the fiercely competitive world of professional tennis. These traits, combined with her on-court brilliance, made her a beloved figure in the sport.  

SECTION 5  
In the years following her retirement, Novotná remained a cherished presence in tennis, coaching and mentoring young players while advocating for greater support for women in sports. Her legacy extends beyond her achievements on the court, as she became a symbol of resilience and grace in the face of adversity. Even in death, her story continues to resonate, reminding us that success is not solely defined by trophies or rankings but by the way we respond to life’s challenges. Jana Novotná may have been remembered for her “choking” moments, but her courage, skill, and kindness have left an indelible mark on the world of tennis—and on the hearts of all who knew her.

The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 EasyJet saw its profits fall 17% last year, with more than £100m lost due to the slump in the pound after the Brexit vote. The airline reported a record year for passenger numbers, flying 80.2 million people, almost 10% more than in 2015-16, on ever fuller planes. But while revenues exceeded £5bn in 2016-17, fares dipped to fill seats in what the chief executive, Carolyn McCall, said was “a difficult year for the aviation industry”. McCall said: “Our planned approach of achieving number one or two positions at Europe’s leading airports, friendly and efficient customer service and a continuous focus on sustainable cost control, has put easyJet at a strategic advantage during a period when there have been bankruptcies and some airlines have struggled operationally.” Profits before tax fell from £494m to £408m. Despite paying a lower dollar price for fuel, the continued weakness of sterling brought additional costs of £101m, easyJet said. The airline will also be prompted by Brexit to change its rules to ensure easyJet is majority owned and controlled by EU nationals after 2019. The following are the beginning sentences of a news article from the Guardian.
-------
 The campaign group that encouraged Paperchase to apologise for its marketing activities with the Daily Mail is pushing for John Lewis, the department store chain, to stop advertising with the newspaper as well as with the Sun and Daily Express. John Lewis has become a prime target for Stop Funding Hate on the back of the launch of its Christmas advert and as retailers increase their spending on advertising as the festive season approaches. Stop Funding Hate has produced a mock advert that depicts the star of last year’s John Lewis Christmas advert – Buster the dog – as unhappy because the retailer is buying adverts with the Mail, Sun, and Express. The video has been shared almost 10,000 times on Twitter and Facebook. Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer and Waitrose are also being targeted by Stop Funding Hate. The organisation was founded last year and says its aim is to take on “divisive hate campaigns” by the Mail, Sun and Express, and persuade advertisers to cease their financial input. Richard Wilson, the founder of Stop Funding Hate, said: “[John Lewis] are a company well known for their ethical values and one that people have a lot of respect for. Customers are saying there is a clash between what the brand stands for and these newspapers. It would be great if John Lewis made a move, but another company could make a move too.” However, John Lewis said it would continue advertising with the newspapers and not bow to the pressure. A spokesperson said: “Withdrawing advertising on the basis of editorial coverage would be inconsistent with our democratic principles, which include freedom of speech and remaining apolitical.” Paperchase announced on Monday that it would not run any marketing campaigns with the Daily Mail and said it was “truly sorry” for running a front-page promotion in Saturday’s edition of the newspaper.
-------

response:
Classic tales of ethical consumerism often highlight the power of public pressure in shaping corporate decisions. In this case, the campaign group Stop Funding Hate has emerged as a formidable force, urging major retailers like John Lewis to reconsider their advertising partnerships with newspapers known for divisive rhetoric. The group’s strategy of leveraging social media to amplify their message has proven effective, as evidenced by the viral spread of their mock advert featuring Buster the dog, the beloved star of John Lewis’s 2016 Christmas campaign. By juxtaposing the retailer’s ethical brand image with its advertising choices, Stop Funding Hate has sparked a wider conversation about the alignment of corporate values with consumer expectations.

The festive season, traditionally a time of heightened advertising spending, has become a critical moment for Stop Funding Hate to push its agenda. With John Lewis’s highly anticipated Christmas advert dominating public attention, the group seized the opportunity to highlight what it perceives as a contradiction between the retailer’s ethos and its advertising choices. The viral video, shared thousands of times across Twitter and Facebook, underscores the growing influence of digital activism in holding corporations accountable. While John Lewis has remained steadfast in its decision to continue advertising with the Mail, Sun, and Express, the campaign has also targeted other major retailers, including Sainsbury’s, Marks & Spencer, and Waitrose, signaling a broader movement toward ethical advertising practices.

Despite the mounting pressure, John Lewis has reaffirmed its commitment to upholding democratic principles, including freedom of speech and maintaining an apolitical stance. The retailer’s spokesperson emphasized that withdrawing advertising based on editorial content would contradict these values. However, the success of Stop Funding Hate’s campaign, as seen with Paperchase’s apology and decision to distance itself from the Daily Mail, suggests that consumer sentiment can indeed drive meaningful change. As the debate over advertising ethics continues, the outcome will likely depend on whether other companies follow suit or adhere to their existing principles, setting a precedent for the balance between corporate responsibility and free expression.
